title: Discovering the Christian sexual ideal - purity culture, marriage equality, gender crisis.
description:
#marriageequality #purityculture #christianity #pornaddiction 

Here is a video that is mostly personal testimony, with some opinions based on what I’ve learned in these areas. 

These are things I would have liked to have been able to discuss with Paul VanderKlay during our rando conversation, but time didn’t allow. 

This is in response to many of his videos on the crisis of men and women, “marriage equality”, and how the church deals with sex in general. Below are my notes for this video. 

My story - 

Parallel story lines - exposure to pornography, raised in a homeschool, purity culture

Teen years were an intensification of both things - 
Gave my speech, “dating with integrity” 

Pursued ministry, when I felt It was the right time pursued marriage 

I had made an idol out of doing things right, and felt that God was punishing me for using pornography -

I didn’t handle rejection well, and I didn’t do much to improve myself in the traditional sense because I thought God would honor me for my religiosity -

Tim Keller’s book counterfeit gods shattered my illusions - 

I realized that I needed to see God’s will, even if it was that I would be single, and if that was God’s desire for my life, I would be happier single than I would be committed. 

God released me from that, and led me to my wife, who I had been friends with for a long time. 
It was scary.
I have zero doubts that this is the woman that God intended me to be with - 
While on paper we fit the criteria of the purity culture, we still have hang ups.
It’s still really hard. 
Marriage is to make us holy, not happy

She pushed me to become more complementarian; it’s better - egalitarian marriage is based on equity, not equality, it sinks to the level of the lowest common denominator.

The true christian sexual ethic is an almost impossible ideal; everyone falls short 
The purity movement was not perfect, and it was too rigid, and some people were hurt by it, but the wholesale abandonment of it is not good 
No system is perfect; but there are less divorces from many of my classmates

Each person has 3 options - live alone, live with the opposite sex, live with the same sex.

For each person, you could rank the difficulty #1,2 & 3. 
For each scenario, some aspects will be difficult and others easy

Why has the church abandoned purity? Joshua harris version was not perfect, but it should have been improved, not thrown away
Why has the church been so weak on pornography? Our failure here is what makes our protests of marriage equality sound so judgemental. We have a log in our own eye.

This is participation in evil - it's a whole thing - all the way down to human trafficking and abortion. 

The true christian sexual ethic 
Abstinence until marriage, no touching the swimsuit areas 
Faithfulness to death, even in light of transgressions by their partner - Hosea
The spouse is to be the lone object of sexual desire and should not be compared to others 
Spouses should serve one another sacrificially, and expect nothing in return. - both partners should consider themselves the lesser
Forgiving all sins
Not sinning against your spouse 

If someone could follow all of this perfectly, but be doing it with someone who is of the same gender, then they would probably be more holy than most people in most heterosexual marriages. 

The true christian sexual ethic is extremely hard - but it creates a safe place where people can be truly happy. If the church had a legitimate argument in the public that we have the true key to sexual fulfilment, it would be spiritual dynamite. It would be devastating to the culture. 

We have civil marriages - churches should be loving and accepting of those who want to attend 

For the church to perform the ceremony is to put a blessing on something that God has not blessed - 

Perhaps we could do away with institutional christian marriages - if we believe in the priesthood of all believers, written about in 1 Peter,  two people could simply choose to be married - but they would be responsible before God to uphold the sexual ethics of the Bible.
